problem: Carson flips over the cards of a standard 52-card deck one at a time. What is the probability that he flips over the ace of spades before any face card (jack, queen or king)?
solution: There are 12 face cards, three from each suit. Within the deck, the 13 relevant cards (the face cards and the ace of spades) are arranged in some order. The probability that the first of these 13 cards is the ace is therefore $\boxed{\frac{1}{13}}$.
model_solution:
Step 1: Determine the total number of cards in a standard deck and the number of face cards in each suit.
Step 2: Calculate the probability of drawing the ace of spades before drawing any face card, which is 1/13, since there is one ace of spades out of 13 possible cards that are face cards (all 3 face cards in the other suits, plus the ace of spades).
Step 3: The probability of drawing the ace of spades before drawing any face card is therefore 1/13, since there are 3 other suits with 3 face cards each, for a total of 9 face cards, and the remaining 39 cards are neither face cards nor the ace of spades.
Step 4: The probability that Carson flips over the ace of spades before any face card is 1/13 times the probability that he doesn't draw the ace of spades until the 14th card, or 6/13, times the probability that he doesn't draw any face card until the 13th card, or 12/13.
Step 5: Calculate the final probability of 1/13 × 6/13 × 12/13 = 72/2197.
Step 6: Calculate the final probability of 1/13 × (13/13 - 1/13) × 12/13 × (13/13 - 3/13) × (12/13 - 3/13) × (11/13 - 3/13) × ... × (1/13 - 3/13) = 1 × 12/13 × 9/13 × 8/13 × 7/13 × 6/13 × 5/13 × 4/13 × 3/13 × 2/13 × 1/13 = 1/4165.
Step 4: The probability that Carson flips over the ace of spades before any face card is 1/13 times the probability that he doesn't draw the ace of spades until the 14th card, or 6/13, times the probability that he doesn't draw any face card until the 13th card, or 12/13.
